"The loss that results to literature
in general fromthis false ideal of
our time can hardly be over-estimated.
People have a careless way of talking
about a 'born liar,' just as they talk
about a 'born poet.' But in both
cases they are wrong. Lying and
poetry are arts--arts, as Plato saw,
not unconnected with each other--and
they require the most careful study,Reference to The Republic, Book 10, 595 ff. (Guy 366). One can trace the connection between lying and poetry to "poiesis," derived from the Greek "ποιεῖν" or "to make." I.e, both are acts of creating something wholly new, which Wilde continues to position in opposition to realism or naturalism's mimitec attempts at REpresentation. See also the addition to Folio 53.
